title: Unprecedented in Parliament’s history: Women lawmakers present 133bills in 4-year
content:
ISLAMABAD, Dec 14 (APP):Contrary to popular belief, the performance of Women legislators in both Houses remained remarkable and in Parliament’s history they presented a significant number of 133 bills for legislative business in just four years (2018 to 2021).
Having representation of only 33% in both Houses, women have participated in parliamentary business, including a number of key legislation pertaining to women rights/human rights, moved some significant resolutions, calling attention notices concerning matters of national importance and budget cut motions.
Women lawmakers have addressed a wide range of issues and their bills were not just women-specific but also included Wages for Skilled Worker, Persons with Disabilities, China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), Child Marriage Restraint, Mental Health Amendment Act, Prevention of Drug Usage in Educational Institution and Human Trafficking Acts etc.
According to the information received through Right to Information(RTI) by Women’s Parliamentary Caucus, female lawmakers have laid 55 private members bills in the National Assembly and 78bills in Senate during ongoing parliamentary years (2018-2021).
Out of these bills, 32 were passed into an act making the ratio of24% bills presented by women and passed by legislative Houses, Talking to this scribe, PTI legislator and federal parliamentary secretary for national history and literary heritage Ghazala Saifi said women, despite not having a large number of legislative positions as MNAs and Senators, have presented some significant resolutions/ notices in the House.
“Our women colleagues realize that being in the parliament of Pakistani as legislator is a big responsibility. Most of the legislation they come forward with are related to human rights”, she added. Ghazala said that in the parliamentary committees women participants bring in the bills through debates and logic.
“Generally women being 50% of our population need to have a higher number in the parliament than the one that exists”, said PTI legislator. Despite this progress, there are politicians who are of the view that this performance still has room for improvement as women legislators are still not responded well by the house as their male counterparts.In this regard, a veteran female legislator from  Muttahida Majlis-e-AmalPakistan (MMAP) Aliya Kamran talked to this scribe terming these statistics ‘not good enough’ on behalf of female legislators.  She said that women lawmakers have come a long way in terms of being recognized in the parliament of Pakistan.However, she said, there are still some glitches that need to be addressed in order to make the role of women more productive and ‘heard’ in the legislative business. She suggested that trainings that are conducted for lawmakers, men or women, should be organized by government institutes instead of international NGOs.These NGOs, she explained, do not have the proper insight of the ground realities that every MNA/MPA faces in their constituencies rather they have their own policies to implement.She also suggested that the role of women from treasury benches should be more forceful and active as they had more young and educated parliamentarians.
